title: 110_s2752
content: The "International Mental Disability and Mental Trauma Care Improvement Act of 2008" aims to enhance the capacity of NGOs to provide mental disability and trauma care training globally. Congress acknowledges the global prevalence of mental disorders and trauma, especially among victims of violence and conflict. Resources for mental disability and trauma care are insufficient in both developed and developing countries, leading to outdated and underfunded practices. The World Health Organization reports that 50% of mental disorders start before age 14, 20% of children worldwide have a mental disorder, and regions with a high youth population lack mental disability care resources. There is a global shortage of mental health professionals, hindering treatment in low- and middle-income countries. In low- and middle-income countries, social stigma and discrimination hinder full participation in society for those with mental disabilities or trauma. The inappropriate institutionalization of these individuals under poor conditions violates human rights standards and does not reflect best-practice care methods. SEC. 104D. Assistance to improve mental disability and trauma care in low- and middle-income countries to address social stigma and discrimination, and ensure best-practice care methods. The President is authorized to award grants to nongovernmental organizations and individuals specializing in mental disability and trauma treatment, training, policy, and research to provide training, advice, and technical expertise for foreign governments in adopting a national mental disability and trauma care framework, initiating system reform, improving treatment options, and providing training for various mental disability and trauma care providers. The President can award grants to organizations and individuals specializing in mental disability and trauma care to provide training, advice, and technical expertise for foreign governments. Eligible applicants must have a proven record of providing mental disability and trauma support and employ evidence-based practices. Organizations seeking grants must submit an application to the President. The President can award grants to organizations and individuals specializing in mental disability and trauma care. Eligible applicants must have a proven record of providing support and employ evidence-based practices. There is authorized funding of at least $10,000,000 for each fiscal year to be made available through the Secretary of State. SEC. 5. ANNUAL REPORT ON MENTAL DISABILITY AND TRAUMA CARE. Section 116(d) of the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 is amended to include mental disability and mental trauma care practices in countries receiving assistance, focusing on patient contact with communities, socialization, and government oversight. The Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 is amended to include mental disability and trauma care practices in countries receiving assistance. This includes aspects such as forced institutionalization, patient-staff ratio, treatment efficacy evaluation, national spending, service provision activities, and integration into public health agendas.
